segment.source: Windows 10 deployment tools (Windows 10)
segment.target: Windows 10 deployment tools (Windows 10)

segment.source: To successfully deploy the Windows 10 operating system and applications for your organization, it is essential that you know about the available tools to help with the process.
segment.target: To successfully deploy the Windows 10 operating system and applications for your organization, it is essential that you know about the available tools to help with the process.

segment.source: Windows 10 deployment tools
segment.target: Windows 10 deployment tools

segment.source: To successfully deploy the Windows 10 operating system and applications for your organization, it is essential that you know about the available tools to help with the process.
segment.target: To successfully deploy the Windows 10 operating system and applications for your organization, it is essential that you know about the available tools to help with the process.

segment.source: In this topic, you will learn about the most commonly used tools for Windows 10 deployment.
segment.target: In this topic, you will learn about the most commonly used tools for Windows 10 deployment.

segment.source: Microsoft provides many tools, services, and solutions.
segment.target: Microsoft provides many tools, services, and solutions.

segment.source: These tools include Windows Deployment Services (WDS), the Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT), the User State Migration Tool (USMT), Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM), Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE), and Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE).
segment.target: These tools include Windows Deployment Services (WDS), the Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT), the User State Migration Tool (USMT), Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM), Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE), and Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE).

segment.source: Keep in mind that these are just tools and not a complete solution on their own.
segment.target: Keep in mind that these are just tools and not a complete solution on their own.

segment.source: It’s when you combine these tools with solutions like Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 1 or Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager that you get the complete deployment solution.
segment.target: It’s when you combine these tools with solutions like Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 1 or Microsoft System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager that you get the complete deployment solution.

segment.source: In this topic, you also learn about different types of reference images that you can build, and why reference images are beneficial for most organizations
segment.target: In this topic, you also learn about different types of reference images that you can build, and why reference images are beneficial for most organizations

segment.source: Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit
segment.target: Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit

segment.source: Windows ADK contains core assessment and deployment tools and technologies, including Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM), Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (Windows ICD), Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM), User State Migration Tool (USMT), Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT), Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE), Windows Assessment Services, Windows Performance Toolkit (WPT), Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT), and Microsoft SQL Server 2012 Express.
segment.target: Windows ADK contains core assessment and deployment tools and technologies, including Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM), Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (Windows ICD), Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM), User State Migration Tool (USMT), Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT), Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE), Windows Assessment Services, Windows Performance Toolkit (WPT), Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT), and Microsoft SQL Server 2012 Express.

segment.source: For more details, see Windows ADK for Windows 10 or Windows ADK for Windows 10 scenarios for IT Pros.
segment.target: For more details, see Windows ADK for Windows 10 or Windows ADK for Windows 10 scenarios for IT Pros.

segment.source: figure 1
segment.target: figure 1

segment.source: Figure 1.
segment.target: Figure 1.

segment.source: The Windows 10 ADK feature selection page.
segment.target: The Windows 10 ADK feature selection page.

segment.source: Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM)
segment.target: Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM)

segment.source: DISM is one of the deployment tools included in the Windows ADK and is used for capturing, servicing, and deploying boot images and operating system images.
segment.target: DISM is one of the deployment tools included in the Windows ADK and is used for capturing, servicing, and deploying boot images and operating system images.

segment.source: DISM services online and offline images.
segment.target: DISM services online and offline images.

segment.source: For example, with DISM you can install the Microsoft .NET Framework 3.5.1 in Windows 10 online, which means that you can start the installation in the running operating system, not that you get the software online.
segment.target: For example, with DISM you can install the Microsoft .NET Framework 3.5.1 in Windows 10 online, which means that you can start the installation in the running operating system, not that you get the software online.

segment.source: The /LimitAccess switch configures DISM to get the files only from a local source:
segment.target: The /LimitAccess switch configures DISM to get the files only from a local source:

segment.source: In Windows 10, you can use Windows PowerShell for many of the functions performed by DISM.exe.
segment.target: In Windows 10, you can use Windows PowerShell for many of the functions performed by DISM.exe.

segment.source: The equivalent command in Windows 10 using PowerShell is:
segment.target: The equivalent command in Windows 10 using PowerShell is:

segment.source: figure 2
segment.target: figure 2

segment.source: Figure 2.
segment.target: Figure 2.

segment.source: Using DISM functions in PowerShell.
segment.target: Using DISM functions in PowerShell.

segment.source: For more information on DISM, see DISM technical reference.
segment.target: For more information on DISM, see DISM technical reference.

segment.source: User State Migration Tool (USMT)
segment.target: User State Migration Tool (USMT)

segment.source: USMT is a backup and restore tool that allows you to migrate user state, data, and settings from one installation to another.
segment.target: USMT is a backup and restore tool that allows you to migrate user state, data, and settings from one installation to another.

segment.source: Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) and System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager use USMT as part of the operating system deployment process.
segment.target: Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) and System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager use USMT as part of the operating system deployment process.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Occasionally, we find that customers are wary of USMT because they believe it requires significant configuration, but, as you will learn below, using USMT is not difficult.
segment.target: Occasionally, we find that customers are wary of USMT because they believe it requires significant configuration, but, as you will learn below, using USMT is not difficult.

segment.source: If you use MDT and Lite Touch to deploy your machines, the USMT feature is automatically configured and extended so that it is easy to use.
segment.target: If you use MDT and Lite Touch to deploy your machines, the USMT feature is automatically configured and extended so that it is easy to use.

segment.source: With MDT, you do nothing at all and USMT just works.
segment.target: With MDT, you do nothing at all and USMT just works.

segment.source: USMT includes several command-line tools, the most important of which are ScanState and LoadState:
segment.target: USMT includes several command-line tools, the most important of which are ScanState and LoadState:

segment.source: ScanState.exe.
segment.target: ScanState.exe.

segment.source: This performs the user-state backup.
segment.target: This performs the user-state backup.

segment.source: LoadState.exe.
segment.target: LoadState.exe.

segment.source: This performs the user-state restore.
segment.target: This performs the user-state restore.

segment.source: UsmtUtils.exe.
segment.target: UsmtUtils.exe.

segment.source: This supplements the functionality in ScanState.exe and LoadState.exe.
segment.target: This supplements the functionality in ScanState.exe and LoadState.exe.

segment.source: In addition to these tools, there are also XML templates that manage which data is migrated.
segment.target: In addition to these tools, there are also XML templates that manage which data is migrated.

segment.source: You can customize the templates, or create new ones, to manage the backup process at a high level of detail.
segment.target: You can customize the templates, or create new ones, to manage the backup process at a high level of detail.

segment.source: USMT uses the following terms for its templates:
segment.target: USMT uses the following terms for its templates:

segment.source: Migration templates.
segment.target: Migration templates.

segment.source: The default templates in USMT.
segment.target: The default templates in USMT.

segment.source: Custom templates.
segment.target: Custom templates.

segment.source: Custom templates that you create.
segment.target: Custom templates that you create.

segment.source: Config template.
segment.target: Config template.

segment.source: An optional template, called Config.xml, which you can use to exclude or include components in a migration without modifying the other standard XML templates.
segment.target: An optional template, called Config.xml, which you can use to exclude or include components in a migration without modifying the other standard XML templates.

segment.source: figure 3
segment.target: figure 3

segment.source: Figure 3.
segment.target: Figure 3.

segment.source: A sample USMT migration file that will exclude .MP3 files on all local drives and include the folder C:Data and all its files, including its subdirectories and their files.
segment.target: A sample USMT migration file that will exclude .MP3 files on all local drives and include the folder C:Data and all its files, including its subdirectories and their files.

segment.source: USMT supports capturing data and settings from Windows Vista and later, and restoring the data and settings to Windows 7 and later (including Windows 10 in both cases).
segment.target: USMT supports capturing data and settings from Windows Vista and later, and restoring the data and settings to Windows 7 and later (including Windows 10 in both cases).

segment.source: It also supports migrating from a 32-bit operating system to a 64-bit operating system, but not the other way around.
segment.target: It also supports migrating from a 32-bit operating system to a 64-bit operating system, but not the other way around.

segment.source: For example, you can use USMT to migrate from Windows 7 x86 to Windows 10 x64.
segment.target: For example, you can use USMT to migrate from Windows 7 x86 to Windows 10 x64.

segment.source: By default USMT migrates many settings, most of which are related to the user profile but also to Control Panel configurations, file types, and more.
segment.target: By default USMT migrates many settings, most of which are related to the user profile but also to Control Panel configurations, file types, and more.

segment.source: The default templates that are used in Windows 10 deployments are MigUser.xml and MigApp.xml.
segment.target: The default templates that are used in Windows 10 deployments are MigUser.xml and MigApp.xml.

segment.source: These two default templates migrate the following data and settings:
segment.target: These two default templates migrate the following data and settings:

segment.source: Folders from each profile, including those from user profiles as well as shared and public profiles.
segment.target: Folders from each profile, including those from user profiles as well as shared and public profiles.

segment.source: For example, the My Documents, My Video, My Music, My Pictures, desktop files, Start menu, Quick Launch settings, and Favorites folders are migrated.
segment.target: For example, the My Documents, My Video, My Music, My Pictures, desktop files, Start menu, Quick Launch settings, and Favorites folders are migrated.

segment.source: Specific file types.
segment.target: Specific file types.

segment.source: USMT templates migrate the following file types: .accdb, .ch3, .csv, .dif, .doc, .dot, .dqy, .iqy, .mcw, .mdb, .mpp, .one, .oqy, .or6, .pot, .ppa, .pps, .ppt, .pre, .pst, .pub, .qdf, .qel, .qph, .qsd, .rqy, .rtf, .scd, .sh3, .slk, .txt, .vl, .vsd, .wk, .wpd, .wps, .wq1, .wri, .xl, .xla, .xlb, .xls.
segment.target: USMT templates migrate the following file types: .accdb, .ch3, .csv, .dif, .doc, .dot, .dqy, .iqy, .mcw, .mdb, .mpp, .one, .oqy, .or6, .pot, .ppa, .pps, .ppt, .pre, .pst, .pub, .qdf, .qel, .qph, .qsd, .rqy, .rtf, .scd, .sh3, .slk, .txt, .vl, .vsd, .wk, .wpd, .wps, .wq1, .wri, .xl, .xla, .xlb, .xls.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The OpenDocument extensions (.odt, .odp, .ods, etc.) that Microsoft Office applications can use are not migrated by default.
segment.target: The OpenDocument extensions (.odt, .odp, .ods, etc.) that Microsoft Office applications can use are not migrated by default.

segment.source: Operating system component settings
segment.target: Operating system component settings

segment.source: Application settings
segment.target: Application settings

segment.source: These are the settings migrated by the default MigUser.xml and MigApp.xml templates.
segment.target: These are the settings migrated by the default MigUser.xml and MigApp.xml templates.

segment.source: For more details on what USMT migrates, see What does USMT migrate?
segment.target: For more details on what USMT migrates, see What does USMT migrate?

segment.source: For more information on the USMT overall, see the USMT technical reference.
segment.target: For more information on the USMT overall, see the USMT technical reference.

segment.source: Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer
segment.target: Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer

segment.source: Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (Windows ICD) is a tool designed to assist with the creation of provisioning packages that can be used to dynamically configure a Windows device (PCs, tablets, and phones).
segment.target: Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (Windows ICD) is a tool designed to assist with the creation of provisioning packages that can be used to dynamically configure a Windows device (PCs, tablets, and phones).

segment.source: This is particularly useful for setting up new devices, without the need for re-imaging the device with a custom image.
segment.target: This is particularly useful for setting up new devices, without the need for re-imaging the device with a custom image.

segment.source: figure 4
segment.target: figure 4

segment.source: Figure 4.
segment.target: Figure 4.

segment.source: Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.
segment.target: Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.

segment.source: Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM)
segment.target: Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM)

segment.source: Windows SIM is an authoring tool for Unattend.xml files.
segment.target: Windows SIM is an authoring tool for Unattend.xml files.

segment.source: When using MDT and/or Configuration Manager, you don’t need Windows SIM very often because those systems automatically update the Unattend.xml file during the deployment, greatly simplifying the process overall.
segment.target: When using MDT and/or Configuration Manager, you don’t need Windows SIM very often because those systems automatically update the Unattend.xml file during the deployment, greatly simplifying the process overall.

segment.source: figure 7
segment.target: figure 7

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.source: Windows answer file opened in Windows SIM.
segment.target: Windows answer file opened in Windows SIM.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows System Image Manager Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows System Image Manager Technical Reference.

segment.source: Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT)
segment.target: Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT)

segment.source: If you don’t use KMS, you can still manage your MAKs centrally with the Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT).
segment.target: If you don’t use KMS, you can still manage your MAKs centrally with the Volume Activation Management Tool (VAMT).

segment.source: With this tool, you can install and manage product keys throughout the organization.
segment.target: With this tool, you can install and manage product keys throughout the organization.

segment.source: VAMT also can activate on behalf of clients without Internet access, acting as a MAK proxy.
segment.target: VAMT also can activate on behalf of clients without Internet access, acting as a MAK proxy.

segment.source: figure 6
segment.target: figure 6

segment.source: Figure 6.
segment.target: Figure 6.

segment.source: The updated Volume Activation Management Tool.
segment.target: The updated Volume Activation Management Tool.

segment.source: VAMT also can be used to create reports, switch from MAK to KMS, manage Active Directory-based activation, and manage Office 2010 and Office 2013 volume activation.
segment.target: VAMT also can be used to create reports, switch from MAK to KMS, manage Active Directory-based activation, and manage Office 2010 and Office 2013 volume activation.

segment.source: VAMT also supports PowerShell (instead of the old command-line tool).
segment.target: VAMT also supports PowerShell (instead of the old command-line tool).

segment.source: For example, if you want to get information from the VAMT database, you can type:
segment.target: For example, if you want to get information from the VAMT database, you can type:

segment.source: For more information on the VAMT, see VAMT technical reference.
segment.target: For more information on the VAMT, see VAMT technical reference.

segment.source: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE)
segment.target: Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE)

segment.source: Windows PE is a “Lite” version of Windows 10 and was created to act as a deployment platform.
segment.target: Windows PE is a “Lite” version of Windows 10 and was created to act as a deployment platform.

segment.source: Windows PE replaces the DOS or Linux boot disks that ruled the deployment solutions of the last decade.
segment.target: Windows PE replaces the DOS or Linux boot disks that ruled the deployment solutions of the last decade.

segment.source: The key thing to know about Windows PE is that, like the operating system, it needs drivers for at least network and storage devices in each PC.
segment.target: The key thing to know about Windows PE is that, like the operating system, it needs drivers for at least network and storage devices in each PC.

segment.source: Luckily Windows PE includes the same drivers as the full Windows 10 operating system, which means much of your hardware will work out of the box.
segment.target: Luckily Windows PE includes the same drivers as the full Windows 10 operating system, which means much of your hardware will work out of the box.

segment.source: figure 7
segment.target: figure 7

segment.source: Figure 7.
segment.target: Figure 7.

segment.source: A machine booted with the Windows ADK default Windows PE boot image.
segment.target: A machine booted with the Windows ADK default Windows PE boot image.

segment.source: For more details on Windows PE, see Windows PE (WinPE).
segment.target: For more details on Windows PE, see Windows PE (WinPE).

segment.source: Windows Recovery Environment
segment.target: Windows Recovery Environment

segment.source: Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) is a diagnostics and recovery toolset included in Windows Vista and later operating systems.
segment.target: Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) is a diagnostics and recovery toolset included in Windows Vista and later operating systems.

segment.source: The latest version of Windows RE is based on Windows PE.
segment.target: The latest version of Windows RE is based on Windows PE.

segment.source: You can also extend Windows RE and add your own tools if needed.
segment.target: You can also extend Windows RE and add your own tools if needed.

segment.source: If a Windows installation fails to start and Windows RE is installed, you will see an automatic failover into Windows RE.
segment.target: If a Windows installation fails to start and Windows RE is installed, you will see an automatic failover into Windows RE.

segment.source: figure 8
segment.target: figure 8

segment.source: Figure 8.
segment.target: Figure 8.

segment.source: A Windows 10 client booted into Windows RE, showing Advanced options.
segment.target: A Windows 10 client booted into Windows RE, showing Advanced options.

segment.source: For more information on Windows RE, see Windows Recovery Environment.
segment.target: For more information on Windows RE, see Windows Recovery Environment.

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services (WDS) has been updated and improved in several ways starting with Windows 8.
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services (WDS) has been updated and improved in several ways starting with Windows 8.

segment.source: Remember that the two main functions you will use are the PXE boot support and multicast.
segment.target: Remember that the two main functions you will use are the PXE boot support and multicast.

segment.source: Most of the changes are related to management and increased performance.
segment.target: Most of the changes are related to management and increased performance.

segment.source: In Windows Server 2012 R2, WDS also can be used for the Network Unlock feature in BitLocker.
segment.target: In Windows Server 2012 R2, WDS also can be used for the Network Unlock feature in BitLocker.

segment.source: figure 9
segment.target: figure 9

segment.source: Figure 9.
segment.target: Figure 9.

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services using multicast to deploy three machines.
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services using multicast to deploy three machines.

segment.source: In Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Deployment Services can be configured for stand-alone mode or for Active Directory integration.
segment.target: In Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Deployment Services can be configured for stand-alone mode or for Active Directory integration.

segment.source: In most scenarios, the Active Directory integration mode is the best option.
segment.target: In most scenarios, the Active Directory integration mode is the best option.

segment.source: WDS also has the capability to manage drivers; however, driver management through MDT and Configuration Manager is more suitable for deployment due to the flexibility offered by both solutions, so you will use them instead.
segment.target: WDS also has the capability to manage drivers; however, driver management through MDT and Configuration Manager is more suitable for deployment due to the flexibility offered by both solutions, so you will use them instead.

segment.source: In WDS, it is possible to pre-stage devices in Active Directory, but here, too, Configuration Manager has that capability built in, and MDT has the ability to use a SQL Server database for pre-staging.
segment.target: In WDS, it is possible to pre-stage devices in Active Directory, but here, too, Configuration Manager has that capability built in, and MDT has the ability to use a SQL Server database for pre-staging.

segment.source: In most scenarios, those solutions are better than the built-in pre-staging function as they allow greater control and management.
segment.target: In most scenarios, those solutions are better than the built-in pre-staging function as they allow greater control and management.

segment.source: Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) configuration
segment.target: Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) configuration

segment.source: In some cases, you need to modify TFTP Maximum Block Size settings for performance tuning reasons, especially when PXE traffic travels through routers and such.
segment.target: In some cases, you need to modify TFTP Maximum Block Size settings for performance tuning reasons, especially when PXE traffic travels through routers and such.

segment.source: In the previous version of WDS, it was possible to change that, but the method of do so—editing the registry—was not user friendly.
segment.target: In the previous version of WDS, it was possible to change that, but the method of do so—editing the registry—was not user friendly.

segment.source: In Windows Server 2012, this has become much easier to do as it can be configured as a setting.
segment.target: In Windows Server 2012, this has become much easier to do as it can be configured as a setting.

segment.source: Also, there are a few new features related to TFTP performance:
segment.target: Also, there are a few new features related to TFTP performance:

segment.source: Scalable buffer management.
segment.target: Scalable buffer management.

segment.source: Allows buffering an entire file instead of a fixed-size buffer for each client, enabling different sessions to read from the same shared buffer.
segment.target: Allows buffering an entire file instead of a fixed-size buffer for each client, enabling different sessions to read from the same shared buffer.

segment.source: Scalable port management.
segment.target: Scalable port management.

segment.source: Provides the capability to service clients with shared UDP port allocation, increasing scalability.
segment.target: Provides the capability to service clients with shared UDP port allocation, increasing scalability.

segment.source: Variable-size transmission window (Variable Windows Extension).
segment.target: Variable-size transmission window (Variable Windows Extension).

segment.source: Improves TFTP performance by allowing the client and server to determine the largest workable window size.
segment.target: Improves TFTP performance by allowing the client and server to determine the largest workable window size.

segment.source: figure 10
segment.target: figure 10

segment.source: Figure 10.
segment.target: Figure 10.

segment.source: TFTP changes are now easy to perform.
segment.target: TFTP changes are now easy to perform.

segment.source: Microsoft Deployment Toolkit 2013 Update 1
segment.target: Microsoft Deployment Toolkit 2013 Update 1

segment.source: MDT 2013 Update 1 is a free deployment solution from Microsoft.
segment.target: MDT 2013 Update 1 is a free deployment solution from Microsoft.

segment.source: It provides end-to-end guidance, best practices, and tools for planning, building, and deploying Windows operating systems.
segment.target: It provides end-to-end guidance, best practices, and tools for planning, building, and deploying Windows operating systems.

segment.source: MDT builds on top of the core deployment tools in the Windows ADK by contributing guidance, reducing complexity, and adding critical features for an enterprise-ready deployment solution.
segment.target: MDT builds on top of the core deployment tools in the Windows ADK by contributing guidance, reducing complexity, and adding critical features for an enterprise-ready deployment solution.

segment.source: MDT 2013 Update 1 has two main parts: the first is Lite Touch, which is a stand-alone deployment solution; the second is Zero Touch, which is an extension to System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager.
segment.target: MDT 2013 Update 1 has two main parts: the first is Lite Touch, which is a stand-alone deployment solution; the second is Zero Touch, which is an extension to System Center 2012 R2 Configuration Manager.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Lite Touch and Zero Touch are marketing names for the two solutions that MDT 2013 supports, and the naming has nothing to do with automation.
segment.target: Lite Touch and Zero Touch are marketing names for the two solutions that MDT 2013 supports, and the naming has nothing to do with automation.

segment.source: You can fully automate the stand-alone MDT 2013 Update 1 solution (Lite Touch), and you can configure the solution integration with Configuration Manager to prompt for information.
segment.target: You can fully automate the stand-alone MDT 2013 Update 1 solution (Lite Touch), and you can configure the solution integration with Configuration Manager to prompt for information.

segment.source: figure 11
segment.target: figure 11

segment.source: Figure 11.
segment.target: Figure 11.

segment.source: The Deployment Workbench in MDT 2013, showing a task sequence.
segment.target: The Deployment Workbench in MDT 2013, showing a task sequence.

segment.source: For more information on MDT 2013 Update 1, see the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit resource center.
segment.target: For more information on MDT 2013 Update 1, see the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit resource center.

segment.source: Microsoft Security Compliance Manager 2013
segment.target: Microsoft Security Compliance Manager 2013

segment.source: Microsoft SCM is a free utility used to create baseline security settings for the Windows client and server environment.
segment.target: Microsoft SCM is a free utility used to create baseline security settings for the Windows client and server environment.

segment.source: The baselines can be exported and then deployed via Group Policy, local policies, MDT, or Configuration Manager.
segment.target: The baselines can be exported and then deployed via Group Policy, local policies, MDT, or Configuration Manager.

segment.source: The current version of Security Compliance Manager includes baselines for Windows 8.1 and several earlier versions of Windows, Windows Server, and Internet Explorer.
segment.target: The current version of Security Compliance Manager includes baselines for Windows 8.1 and several earlier versions of Windows, Windows Server, and Internet Explorer.

segment.source: figure 12
segment.target: figure 12

segment.source: Figure 12.
segment.target: Figure 12.

segment.source: The SCM console showing a baseline configuration for a fictional client's computer security compliance.
segment.target: The SCM console showing a baseline configuration for a fictional client's computer security compliance.

segment.source: Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack
segment.target: Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack

segment.source: MDOP is a suite of technologies available to Software Assurance customers through an additional subscription.
segment.target: MDOP is a suite of technologies available to Software Assurance customers through an additional subscription.

segment.source: The following components are included in the MDOP suite:
segment.target: The following components are included in the MDOP suite:

segment.source: Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V).
segment.target: Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V).

segment.source: App-V 5.0 provides an integrated platform, more flexible virtualization, and powerful management for virtualized applications.
segment.target: App-V 5.0 provides an integrated platform, more flexible virtualization, and powerful management for virtualized applications.

segment.source: With the release of App-V 5.0 SP3, you have support to run virtual applications on Windows 10.
segment.target: With the release of App-V 5.0 SP3, you have support to run virtual applications on Windows 10.

segment.source: Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V).
segment.target: Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V).

segment.source: UE-V monitors the changes that are made by users to application settings and Windows operating system settings.
segment.target: UE-V monitors the changes that are made by users to application settings and Windows operating system settings.

segment.source: The user settings are captured and centralized to a settings storage location.
segment.target: The user settings are captured and centralized to a settings storage location.

segment.source: These settings can then be applied to the different computers that are accessed by the user, including desktop computers, laptop computers, and virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) sessions.
segment.target: These settings can then be applied to the different computers that are accessed by the user, including desktop computers, laptop computers, and virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) sessions.

segment.source: Microsoft Advanced Group Policy Management (AGPM).
segment.target: Microsoft Advanced Group Policy Management (AGPM).

segment.source: AGPM enables advanced management of Group Policy objects by providing change control, offline editing, and role-based delegation.
segment.target: AGPM enables advanced management of Group Policy objects by providing change control, offline editing, and role-based delegation.

segment.source: Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolset (DaRT).
segment.target: Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolset (DaRT).

segment.source: DaRT provides additional tools that extend Windows RE to help you troubleshoot and repair your machines.
segment.target: DaRT provides additional tools that extend Windows RE to help you troubleshoot and repair your machines.

segment.source: Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring (MBAM).
segment.target: Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring (MBAM).

segment.source: MBAM is an administrator interface used to manage BitLocker drive encryption.
segment.target: MBAM is an administrator interface used to manage BitLocker drive encryption.

segment.source: It allows you to configure your enterprise with the correct BitLocker encryption policy options, as well as monitor compliance with these policies.
segment.target: It allows you to configure your enterprise with the correct BitLocker encryption policy options, as well as monitor compliance with these policies.

segment.source: For more information on the benefits of an MDOP subscription, see Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack.
segment.target: For more information on the benefits of an MDOP subscription, see Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack.

segment.source: Internet Explorer Administration Kit 11
segment.target: Internet Explorer Administration Kit 11

segment.source: There has been a version of IEAK for every version of Internet Explorer since 3.0.
segment.target: There has been a version of IEAK for every version of Internet Explorer since 3.0.

segment.source: It gives you the capability to customize Internet Explorer as you would like.
segment.target: It gives you the capability to customize Internet Explorer as you would like.

segment.source: The end result of using IEAK is an Internet Explorer package that can be deployed unattended.
segment.target: The end result of using IEAK is an Internet Explorer package that can be deployed unattended.

segment.source: The wizard creates one .exe file and one .msi file.
segment.target: The wizard creates one .exe file and one .msi file.

segment.target: figure 13

segment.source: Figure 13.
segment.target: Figure 13.

segment.source: The User Experience selection screen in IEAK 11.
segment.target: The User Experience selection screen in IEAK 11.

segment.source: To download IEAK 11, see the Internet Explorer Administration Kit (IEAK) Information and Downloads page.
segment.target: To download IEAK 11, see the Internet Explorer Administration Kit (IEAK) Information and Downloads page.

segment.source: Windows Server Update Services
segment.target: Windows Server Update Services

segment.source: WSUS is a server role in Windows Server 2012 R2 that enables you to maintain a local repository of Microsoft updates and then distribute them to machines on your network.
segment.target: WSUS is a server role in Windows Server 2012 R2 that enables you to maintain a local repository of Microsoft updates and then distribute them to machines on your network.

segment.source: WSUS offers approval control and reporting of update status in your environment.
segment.target: WSUS offers approval control and reporting of update status in your environment.

segment.source: figure 14
segment.target: figure 14

segment.source: Figure 14.
segment.target: Figure 14.

segment.source: The Windows Server Update Services console.
segment.target: The Windows Server Update Services console.

segment.source: For more information on WSUS, see the Windows Server Update Services Overview.
segment.target: For more information on WSUS, see the Windows Server Update Services Overview.

segment.source: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface
segment.target: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface

segment.source: For many years BIOS has been the industry standard for booting a PC.
segment.target: For many years BIOS has been the industry standard for booting a PC.

segment.source: BIOS has served us well, but it is time to replace it with something better.
segment.target: BIOS has served us well, but it is time to replace it with something better.

segment.source: UEFI is the replacement for BIOS, so it is important to understand the differences between BIOS and UEFI.
segment.target: UEFI is the replacement for BIOS, so it is important to understand the differences between BIOS and UEFI.

segment.source: In this section, you learn the major differences between the two and how they affect operating system deployment.
segment.target: In this section, you learn the major differences between the two and how they affect operating system deployment.

segment.source: Introduction to UEFI
segment.target: Introduction to UEFI

segment.source: BIOS has been in use for approximately 30 years.
segment.target: BIOS has been in use for approximately 30 years.

segment.source: Even though it clearly has proven to work, it has some limitations, including:
segment.target: Even though it clearly has proven to work, it has some limitations, including:

segment.source: 16-bit code
segment.target: 16-bit code

segment.source: 1 MB address space
segment.target: 1 MB address space

segment.source: Poor performance on ROM initialization
segment.target: Poor performance on ROM initialization

segment.source: MBR maximum bootable disk size of 2.2 TB
segment.target: MBR maximum bootable disk size of 2.2 TB

segment.source: As the replacement to BIOS, UEFI has many features that Windows can and will use.
segment.target: As the replacement to BIOS, UEFI has many features that Windows can and will use.

segment.source: With UEFI, you can benefit from:
segment.target: With UEFI, you can benefit from:

segment.source: Support for large disks.
segment.target: Support for large disks.

segment.source: UEFI requires a GUID Partition Table (GPT) based disk, which means a limitation of roughly 16.8 million TB in disk size and more than 100 primary disks.
segment.target: UEFI requires a GUID Partition Table (GPT) based disk, which means a limitation of roughly 16.8 million TB in disk size and more than 100 primary disks.

segment.source: Faster boot time.
segment.target: Faster boot time.

segment.source: UEFI does not use INT 13, and that improves boot time, especially when it comes to resuming from hibernate.
segment.target: UEFI does not use INT 13, and that improves boot time, especially when it comes to resuming from hibernate.

segment.source: Multicast deployment.
segment.target: Multicast deployment.

segment.source: UEFI firmware can use multicast directly when it boots up.
segment.target: UEFI firmware can use multicast directly when it boots up.

segment.source: In WDS, MDT, and Configuration Manager scenarios, you need to first boot up a normal Windows PE in unicast and then switch into multicast.
segment.target: In WDS, MDT, and Configuration Manager scenarios, you need to first boot up a normal Windows PE in unicast and then switch into multicast.

segment.source: With UEFI, you can run multicast from the start.
segment.target: With UEFI, you can run multicast from the start.

segment.source: Compatibility with earlier BIOS.
segment.target: Compatibility with earlier BIOS.

segment.source: Most of the UEFI implementations include a compatibility support module (CSM) that emulates BIOS.
segment.target: Most of the UEFI implementations include a compatibility support module (CSM) that emulates BIOS.

segment.source: CPU-independent architecture.
segment.target: CPU-independent architecture.

segment.source: Even if BIOS can run both 32- and 64-bit versions of firmware, all firmware device drivers on BIOS systems must also be 16-bit, and this affects performance.
segment.target: Even if BIOS can run both 32- and 64-bit versions of firmware, all firmware device drivers on BIOS systems must also be 16-bit, and this affects performance.

segment.source: One of the reasons is the limitation in addressable memory, which is only 64 KB with BIOS.
segment.target: One of the reasons is the limitation in addressable memory, which is only 64 KB with BIOS.

segment.source: CPU-independent drivers.
segment.target: CPU-independent drivers.

segment.source: On BIOS systems, PCI add-on cards must include a ROM that contains a separate driver for all supported CPU architectures.
segment.target: On BIOS systems, PCI add-on cards must include a ROM that contains a separate driver for all supported CPU architectures.

segment.source: That is not needed for UEFI because UEFI has the ability to use EFI Byte Code (EBC) images, which allow for a processor-independent device driver environment.
segment.target: That is not needed for UEFI because UEFI has the ability to use EFI Byte Code (EBC) images, which allow for a processor-independent device driver environment.

segment.source: Flexible pre-operating system environment.
segment.target: Flexible pre-operating system environment.

segment.source: UEFI can perform many functions for you.
segment.target: UEFI can perform many functions for you.

segment.source: You just need an UEFI application, and you can perform diagnostics and automatic repairs, and call home to report errors.
segment.target: You just need an UEFI application, and you can perform diagnostics and automatic repairs, and call home to report errors.

segment.source: Secure boot.
segment.target: Secure boot.

segment.source: Windows 8 and later can use the UEFI firmware validation process, called secure boot, which is defined in UEFI 2.3.1.
segment.target: Windows 8 and later can use the UEFI firmware validation process, called secure boot, which is defined in UEFI 2.3.1.

segment.source: Using this process, you can ensure that UEFI launches only a verified operating system loader and that malware cannot switch the boot loader.
segment.target: Using this process, you can ensure that UEFI launches only a verified operating system loader and that malware cannot switch the boot loader.

segment.source: Versions
segment.target: Versions

segment.source: UEFI Version 2.3.1B is the version required for Windows 8 and later logo compliance.
segment.target: UEFI Version 2.3.1B is the version required for Windows 8 and later logo compliance.

segment.source: Later versions have been released to address issues; a small number of machines may need to upgrade their firmware to fully support the UEFI implementation in Windows 8 and later.
segment.target: Later versions have been released to address issues; a small number of machines may need to upgrade their firmware to fully support the UEFI implementation in Windows 8 and later.

segment.source: Hardware support for UEFI
segment.target: Hardware support for UEFI

segment.source: In regard to UEFI, hardware is divided into four device classes:
segment.target: In regard to UEFI, hardware is divided into four device classes:

segment.source: Class 0 devices.
segment.target: Class 0 devices.

segment.source: This is the UEFI definition for a BIOS, or non-UEFI, device.
segment.target: This is the UEFI definition for a BIOS, or non-UEFI, device.

segment.source: Class 1 devices.
segment.target: Class 1 devices.

segment.source: These devices behave like a standard BIOS machine, but they run EFI internally.
segment.target: These devices behave like a standard BIOS machine, but they run EFI internally.

segment.source: They should be treated as normal BIOS-based machines.
segment.target: They should be treated as normal BIOS-based machines.

segment.source: Class 1 devices use a CSM to emulate BIOS.
segment.target: Class 1 devices use a CSM to emulate BIOS.

segment.source: These older devices are no longer manufactured.
segment.target: These older devices are no longer manufactured.

segment.source: Class 2 devices.
segment.target: Class 2 devices.

segment.source: These devices have the capability to behave as a BIOS- or a UEFI-based machine, and the boot process or the configuration in the firmware/BIOS determines the mode.
segment.target: These devices have the capability to behave as a BIOS- or a UEFI-based machine, and the boot process or the configuration in the firmware/BIOS determines the mode.

segment.source: Class 2 devices use a CSM to emulate BIOS.
segment.target: Class 2 devices use a CSM to emulate BIOS.

segment.source: These are the most common type of devices currently available.
segment.target: These are the most common type of devices currently available.

segment.source: Class 3 devices.
segment.target: Class 3 devices.

segment.source: These are UEFI-only devices, which means you must run an operating system that supports only UEFI.
segment.target: These are UEFI-only devices, which means you must run an operating system that supports only UEFI.

segment.source: Those operating systems include Windows 8, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2012, and Windows Server 2012 R2.
segment.target: Those operating systems include Windows 8, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2012, and Windows Server 2012 R2.

segment.source: Windows 7 is not supported on these class 3 devices.
segment.target: Windows 7 is not supported on these class 3 devices.

segment.source: Class 3 devices do not have a CSM to emulate BIOS.
segment.target: Class 3 devices do not have a CSM to emulate BIOS.

segment.source: Windows support for UEFI
segment.target: Windows support for UEFI

segment.source: Microsoft started with support for EFI 1.10 on servers and then added support for UEFI on both clients and servers.
segment.target: Microsoft started with support for EFI 1.10 on servers and then added support for UEFI on both clients and servers.

segment.source: With UEFI 2.3.1, there are both x86 and x64 versions of UEFI.
segment.target: With UEFI 2.3.1, there are both x86 and x64 versions of UEFI.

segment.source: Windows 10 supports both.
segment.target: Windows 10 supports both.

segment.source: However, UEFI does not support cross-platform boot.
segment.target: However, UEFI does not support cross-platform boot.

segment.source: This means that a computer that has UEFI x64 can run only a 64-bit operating system, and a computer that has UEFI x86 can run only a 32-bit operating system.
segment.target: This means that a computer that has UEFI x64 can run only a 64-bit operating system, and a computer that has UEFI x86 can run only a 32-bit operating system.

segment.source: How UEFI is changing operating system deployment
segment.target: How UEFI is changing operating system deployment

segment.source: There are many things that affect operating system deployment as soon as you run on UEFI/EFI-based hardware.
segment.target: There are many things that affect operating system deployment as soon as you run on UEFI/EFI-based hardware.

segment.source: Here are considerations to keep in mind when working with UEFI devices:
segment.target: Here are considerations to keep in mind when working with UEFI devices:

segment.source: Switching from BIOS to UEFI in the hardware is easy, but you also need to reinstall the operating system because you need to switch from MBR/NTFS to GPT/FAT32 and NTFS.
segment.target: Switching from BIOS to UEFI in the hardware is easy, but you also need to reinstall the operating system because you need to switch from MBR/NTFS to GPT/FAT32 and NTFS.

segment.source: When you deploy to a Class 2 device, make sure the boot option you select matches the setting you want to have.
segment.target: When you deploy to a Class 2 device, make sure the boot option you select matches the setting you want to have.

segment.source: It is common for old machines to have several boot options for BIOS but only a few for UEFI, or vice versa.
segment.target: It is common for old machines to have several boot options for BIOS but only a few for UEFI, or vice versa.

segment.source: When deploying from media, remember the media has to be FAT32 for UEFI, and FAT32 has a file-size limitation of 4GB.
segment.target: When deploying from media, remember the media has to be FAT32 for UEFI, and FAT32 has a file-size limitation of 4GB.

segment.source: UEFI does not support cross-platform booting; therefore, you need to have the correct boot media (32- or 64-bit).
segment.target: UEFI does not support cross-platform booting; therefore, you need to have the correct boot media (32- or 64-bit).

segment.source: For more information on UEFI, see the UEFI firmware overview and related resources.
segment.target: For more information on UEFI, see the UEFI firmware overview and related resources.
